urn:contentItem:5Y6N-X761-JB4M-V26K-00000-00Mass propaganda used to be difficult, but Facebook made it easy2020-02-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:09:13ZLexisNexisMass propaganda used to be difficult, but Facebook made it easyDannagal G. Young;Shannon C. McGregor

Last month, Facebook announced that it will not limit microtargeting capabilities for political ads. Nor will it police factual accuracy of those ads. As much as the spread of blatant falsehoods on social media rankles Americans, that second judgment may be wise, as Facebook has neither the capacity nor the legitimacy to act as arbiters of truth. But the propagation of falsehoods along with the targeting to narrow but receptive audiences is a dangerous combination. And recent public opinion data suggest that the public overwhelmingly agrees.

While concern over misinformation may seem like a post-2016 phenomenon, it isn't. In the 1940s, the rapid rise in mass media and the devastating use of mediated propaganda by the Nazis caused great alarm. To alleviate fears that this propaganda would overwhelm the United States, Columbia University sociologists Paul Lazarsfeld and Robert Merton suggested that mass persuasion through the American media system was quite difficult. They outlined three criteria necessary for its success - monopolization, canalization and supplementation - and explained how these criteria were nearly impossible to meet in the media system at the time.

But our media system has changed, and the reasons cited in this scholarly plea for calm in 1948 are the very reasons we should be worried in 2020 - and why we must demand regulation of Big Tech right now.

When Lazarsfeld and Merton were writing, the American media landscape was dominated by broadcast radio and newspapers. By 1945, radios were in virtually every home and the broadcast industry was consolidated, with four networks owning almost all the radio stations in the United States.

Lazarsfeld and Merton argued that propaganda in this media ecosystem was unlikely to work, because it required conditions that didn't exist. First among these was "monopolization," or the absence of countermessaging. In 1948, because of the size of the audiences tuning into network radio shows, media industries made money by selling national ads broadcast to giant mass audiences. While there would be ads for Coke, there would also be ads for Pepsi. While there would be ads for Republicans, there would also be ads for Democrats. The means did not exist to segment audiences with precision so that Coke-drinking Republicans only received ads for Coke and Republican candidates.

This inability to target messages with precision had another consequence that made a successful propaganda campaign unlikely: According to Lazarsfeld and Merton, propaganda could not persuade people of something totally alien to their beliefs. Successful propaganda required "canalization," they said; it must build upon preexisting attitudes and values to be successful. Water couldn't flow in the correct direction without a canal, the thought went. With media having such a broad reach, there was no capacity to target audiences based on preexisting views - so strategic canalization was impossible.

But the mass audience that Lazarsfeld and Merton described hasn't existed for over 40 years. As cable television became popularized in the 1980s, media outlets proliferated; audiences increased in number but had shrunk in size. Network executives crafted niche programming to attract certain kinds of viewers to sell to advertisers; hence the birth of MTV, BET and Playboy (to name a few) between 1979 and 1982.

With early Internet access reaching homes in the 1990s, developers built upon this now-familiar "fragmented media model" that had dominated the economics of cable. Most early commercial websites were thus aimed at audiences and consumers whom corporations would target with information, goods and services without necessarily capitalizing on the inherent interactivity of the technology.

But, the dot-com crash of the early 2000s motivated web developers and venture capitalists to reconsider whether that economic model could sustain the Internet. It had failed to capitalize on the Internet's unique affordances: The technology allowed users to create and share information thanks to the decentralization of control of information across the network - there was no gatekeeper. In fact, this was the reason the Department of Defense invested in the creation of the Internet during the Cold War: to decentralize control over information in the event that a military attack should destroy records, data, plans or documents.

In the aftermath of the dot-com crash, these properties became the focus of new platform development. Sometimes called Web 2.0, or the Social Web, platforms like Myspace (2003), Facebook (2004), YouTube (2005) and Twitter (2006) capitalized on the decentralized logic of the network to empower users to create and share content, rate and like content, and connect with one another.

Doing so offered up another profit model - turning every share, like, click, photo and location tag into data points used to inform the sale of microtargeted audiences to advertisers. Unlike cable TV, which could only target audiences based upon the type of programming they tuned into, now advertisers could use individual-level behaviors - including social behaviors - to inform the content, aesthetics and reach of ads.

These economic and technological changes have created a media environment that satisfies the precise conditions that Lazarsfeld and Merton said were requirements for a successful propaganda campaign in 1948. In the past, authoritarian regimes wielded state-run media (hence, monopolization) to utilize propaganda to capitalize on preexisting beliefs, attitudes and fears (hence, canalization). While a state-run media infrastructure does not exist in the United States, thanks to Facebook's microtargeting features, individual citizens can still find themselves in information environments monopolized by just one side.

The Guardian recently revealed just how specialized these microtargeting efforts can be: "158,909 (or 72 percent) of the ads that [President] Trump's campaign ran in 2019 were seen by between zero and 999 Facebook users." And because of the low cost of such microtargeting, these ads are cheap to run. It is possible to create hundreds, and even thousands, of distinct political ads on the same theme - each variety targeted to groups of users that share a unique mix of identities and interests. The Trump campaign did exactly this in 2016, running 5.9 million total Facebook ads from June to November.

Facebook is also a canalization machine. People are targeted based on interests, purchases, demographics, political characteristics - and the synergy between these categories. Facebook's Custom Audiences feature allows political campaigns to upload lists of users to target with ads. These lists are typically drawn from voter files (provided by parties or consulting firms) and email lists (drawn from supporters or from other campaigns).

Facebook also touts Look-a-like Audiences, which allow campaigns to target entirely new people who look just like the people already on advertisers' lists. According to Facebook, once advertisers upload a Custom Audience, Facebook's Look-a-like tool "identifies the common qualities of the people in it ... and finds similar people."

Facebook guarantees the success of these tools by building close relationships with campaign operatives, ensuring that campaigns have the skills to capitalize upon these tools. Trump's campaign didn't come up with their targeting plan independently, but by working side-by-side with Facebook employees who facilitated canalization.

There is one more important piece of the puzzle. The two Columbia sociologists told Americans they had little to worry about in 1948 because media propaganda needs to be supplemented by interpersonal communication to be successful. While the audiences for popular radio broadcasts were large, there was little opportunity for show producers to interact with audiences. Nor were there mechanisms for the thousands of radio show listeners to know who else was in the audience, much less to interact.

But social media platforms were built for such interaction. We share stories along with new information, recontextualized from our personal perspectives. We receive stories from news outlets, but that have been shared - and deemed credible by - friends and family. And we respond quickly, reacting to mediated information and sharing it as our own.

Importantly, this is also the aspect of social media that is perhaps most democratizing. By connecting individuals with one other, these platforms facilitate political discussion, collective action and grass roots activism - all of which are healthy aspects of democratic life.

But today's tech platforms also facilitate all three criteria - monopolization, canalization and supplementation. As such, a successful propaganda campaign, one that could efficiently cultivate racist, misogynist, anti-Semitic, anti-democratic or otherwise dangerous views, is clearly possible.

This makes it incumbent upon regulators to act, and act quickly. Self-regulation isn't realistic; these companies' interests are profoundly different from the public interest.

Regulation must limit the extent to which platforms allow political advertisers to target individuals (limiting both the nature and specificity of user affinities used to target ads and the number of voters they can reach at once relative to the size of the electoral contest).

Importantly, there is overwhelming public support for limits on microtargeting. According to new data gathered by the Knight Foundation in concert with Gallup, 72 percent of Americans oppose the use of any individual data for microtargeting by political campaigns. This is a rare nonpartisan issue - 75 percent of Republicans and 69 percent of Democrats believe no individual-level data should be used by political campaigns to target them online.

Successful regulation must also compel platforms to share the criteria being used to create custom and look-a-like audiences. Such transparency would allow counter speech.

Finally, regulation must require and facilitate data access to academic researchers so that we may study these phenomena outside of their corporate watchful eye.

Microtargeting is far from inherently bad. Small campaigns and grass-roots organizations use Facebook's cost-effective microtargeting tools to build lists of supporters, solicit donations and mobilize volunteers, all of which benefit voters and candidates. But, without rules governing microtargeting criteria and transparency, these same tools can be used to entrench ideologies or mobilize hate groups.

In 1948, it was appropriate for social scientists to tell the public to relax about the exploitability of America's mass media infrastructure by propagandists. But today, it's equally appropriate for social scientists to sound the alarm. We need regulation, and we need it now.

Siloed payment systems ‘stupid’

Questions over Libra’s money laundering controls

Banga does not understand how Libra makes money

Few companies have more to gain from the march of globalisation and digitisation than Mastercard. The payment network’s strength is its worldwide reach, and its growth is driven by the move from cash to electronic transactions.

So chief executive Ajay Banga is unequivocal about governments’ attempts to break the global payments system into national fiefdoms.

“The economic cost of building siloed systems in a world where citizens travel globally is really stupid, and where crime travels globally is even more stupid, and where technology is completely global is even three times more stupid,” he says, with emphasis on each “stupid”.

Mr Banga sees more governments edging towards nationalisation of consumer payments systems, and fears that consumers, wary of their privacy, could shift back towards cash.

Right now, though, Mastercard is in a strong position. Mr Banga, 60, says the company can hit 7-8 per cent revenue growth every year, “if [we] just fog the mirror and don’t make thousands of mistakes”. Mastercard takes a fraction of a percentage of every transaction on its network, and also sells services to banks and merchants.

Last week Mastercard reported 2019 revenue of $17bn, more than triple the level of a decade ago, when Mr Banga took the helm. Profit has grown faster still, and the company’s share price has risen from $20 to $320 under his tenure.

Globally, payments on credit and debit cards have quadrupled over the past 10 years, according to The Nilson Report, a data provider.

Mr Banga, who previously ran Citigroup’s operations in Asia, does not take growth for granted. “Global companies [could] get disallowed from working in a bunch of big markets around the world because these markets begin to say ‘I don’t want you around’. It gets exacerbated in days of populism and nationalism that we’re going through.”

In recent years, several countries from Russia to Mr Banga’s native India, have either developed national payments networks or lent government support to local payment groups. China has a fully nationalised payments network.

It is an established phenomenon, says Mr Banga. “This idea of finding a way to have national control on certain kinds of payments is not new — it’s a fantasy that’s been going on for a long time.” He notes that France, Australia, Brazil and Mexico have all tried to build national payments networks, with limited success.

The problem with local networks is threefold, he argues. They require massive redundant investment; they are cumbersome or useless for cross-border transactions; and they fragment the data the network throws off, hindering the analytic work needed to track fraud and crime.

Mr Banga says that when he talks to national regulators “they’ll garb [nationalisation] as national security”. He points out in response that national data is of limited use when terrorists do not respect borders — and that domestic banks hold more country specific data anyway. “They all say, ‘that’s a good point’.”

“For national parochial reasons or [to help] domestic business . . . [governments] may still get prompted to chase me down. But now we’re not talking principles; now we’re talking good old dirty politics.”

Government parochialism is not the only threat. The movement towards electronic payments could switch the other way “because people get scared of digital transparency”, he says. “An event like Facebook- Cambridge Analytica actually could set you back because it could create the feeling among people like you and me who say, ‘do I really want everything to be visible to other people? Because other people are taking advantage of what they see of me. I don’t like that. I want my life back.’”

Mastercard is parsimonious about the user data it collects. Card networks receive only four pieces of information with each transaction: an account number, the value of the transaction, a time and a merchant code. This makes it possible for the company to keep high standards for data ownership and transparency, and insist that the customer “receive some benefit” any time their data is used.

Concerns about data integrity help explain why Mastercard pulled out of Libra, the Facebook-led digital currency project that was unveiled last year. Mr Banga likes the idea of a global currency and joined the association of companies backing Libra, but concerns over compliance and the business model led him to withdraw.

The association’s key members would not give a hard commitment to “not do anything that is not fully compliant with local law”. He points to due diligence considerations such as know your client, anti money laundering, data management, “all that . . . every time you talked to the main proponents of Libra, I said ‘Would you put that in writing?’ They wouldn’t.”

He also did not see how Libra would make money, and “when you don’t understand how money gets made, it gets made in ways you don’t like”. Finally, he was alarmed that Facebook had positioned Libra as a financial inclusion tool but then proposed linking it to a proprietary digital wallet, Calibra.

“It went from this altruistic idea into their own wallet. I’m like: ‘this doesn’t sound right’ . . . For financial inclusion, the government has got to pay you in this [currency], you’ve got to receive it as an instrument you can understand, and you have to be able to use it to buy rice and cycles. If you get paid in Libra [coin] . . . which go into Calibras, which go back into pounds to buy rice, I don’t understand how that works.”

Arguably, Mr Banga also has self-serving reasons for pulling back from Libra. Lisa Ellis, payments analyst at MoffettNathanson, thinks that it is possible that a blockchain-based payments system could, years in the future, grow into a real-time global payments network — posing an “existential threat” to private networks such as Mastercard.

Analysts also fret that as digital wallets such as Apple Pay or India’s Paytm gain traction, and more transactions are conducted on big tech platforms such as those belonging to Google or Amazon, Mastercard’s place in the payments ecosystem will become less prominent.

Mr Banga is unperturbed: “We have 30,000 plus banks around the world connected with 60m merchants with billions of people in 200 countries with local legal regs of every country built into the system. Everybody, even the digital giants, realises that is a [lot] of heavy lifting to try and do,” and that it is “better, faster, cheaper” to partner with Mastercard.

Most analysts agree. “It’s not easy to break into payments — many entrants have found that out, quickly and the hard way,” says Sanjay Sakhrani of KBW. But, he says, it could be different with big tech companies “if they want ownership of everything” in ecommerce.

Surely as the tech players gain scale, they will at least ask Mastercard to lower its fees? Of course they will, says Mr Banga. “He who has bigger shoes is going to take them off and beat your goddamn head in . . . a bigger bank negotiates harder than a smaller bank. A bigger merchant negotiates harder than a poorer merchant. A bigger government negotiates harder than a smaller government. So China negotiates differently than Vietnam. It’s just reality.”

urn:contentItem:5T16-7041-DXH2-6399-00000-00Mastercard Inc at Cantor Fitzgerald Innovation Summit - Final2018-08-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:09:13ZLexisNexis080618a11713477.777Mastercard Incat Cantor FitzgeraldInnovation Summit - Final

Corporate Participants

* Linda Kirkpatrick

Mastercard Incorporated- EVP of U.S. Market Development

Conference Call Participants

* Joseph Dean Foresi

Cantor Fitzgerald & Co., Research Division - Analyst

Presentation

JOSEPH DEAN FORESI, ANALYST, CANTOR FITZGERALD & CO., RESEARCH DIVISION: Okay. Well, it turned out the other way. So we have Linda Kirkpatrick here from Mastercard. And maybe we can just start with, Linda, maybe you talking a little bit about your role at Mastercard and your responsibilities there.

LINDA KIRKPATRICK, EVP OF U.S. MARKET DEVELOPMENT, MASTERCARD INCORPORATED: Sure. I lead up a group called U.S. market development, and that's our U.S. merchant relationships, acquiring bank relationships and business development efforts on the co-brand, commercial, prepaid, public sector and healthcare side.

Questions and Answers

JOSEPH DEAN FORESI: And so within your role there, maybe you could just expand a little bit on your interaction with the merchant. And how does that fit with the overall Mastercard strategy and stakeholder base?

LINDA KIRKPATRICK: Sure. So the acceptance strategy within Mastercard is very closely linked to both our vision for a world beyond cash as well as our strategy. We have a 3-pronged strategy: to grow our core business; to diversify our customers and the geographies in which we operate; and to build new products and new channels, particularly in digital. So when you think about the merchant and acceptance organization, that fits squarely within the diversified bucket. We look to grow the number of places that our products can be used. And we also look to those customers as consumers of our products and services and solutions. So it's really inextricably linked to the overall strategy for the company, and we've placed a significant amount of investment on that side of the house. And when you think about any Four Party Payments Model, you need both the issuance and the acceptance side to work in tandem to be truly successful. So it's a big component of our overall focus.

JOSEPH DEAN FORESI: Got it. And maybe we can delve just a little bit into cobranding and the strategy associated with it, how you handle the cobranding and maybe the competitive environment associated with it.

LINDA KIRKPATRICK: The cobranding environment is extremely competitive right now. If we rewind about a decade ago, there was a very different dynamic in the marketplace. You had a co-brand environment that was largely issuer-led. So you may have had a retailer or an airline interested in developing a program. They would go, they would approach a bank and say, "We want to either create a program or renew a program." And the issuer would bring the network along for the ride. The network was more of the back end, wasn't really involved in the selection process on the part of the merchant and wasn't really interwoven into the fabric of the pitch for the strategy. Today, merchants are much more in the driver's seat when it comes to selecting who their partners are. And why has this changed? Well, there was a period, again about a decade ago, where issuers were less interested in funding co-brand value propositions. You had the impact of regulation. You had the impact of 2008, and many of them were exiting the business. But what's happened over time is merchants have really seen the value in driving loyalty with their consumer base. Many merchants connect their loyalty program very directly to their co-brand program. In some instances, they're one and the same. And they look at the ecosystem and the partners that participate on the issuing side of the network side as an opportunity for them to fund up their value proposition. So it's a great deal for them. They can more fully optimize their loyalty program. They can increase their value proposition, increase the affinity that their consumers have for their brand and get others to help fund that participation. So from our perspective, it's been terrific. We've had a terrific success. Merchants have really seen the value of partnering with Mastercard very directly. We now participate very directly in a very separate pitch to the merchant. They appreciate the value that we bring to the table, vis-Ã -vis data and analytics, fraud, safety and security capabilities, marketing and loyalty. We've had a couple of larger flips over the past year or 2. You may have seen flips from our competition from Kroger from L.L.Bean and most recently from Cabela's. So those are all very meaningful to our business. And if you look outside the industry, there are a number of folks who report on the size of the marketplace. And from a Mastercard perspective, we have about 45% of the co-brand share in the marketplace. So it's above our natural share, which is less than that at this point in time. So we're very, very proud of that success. And from our perspective, it's important because, one, it helps us with the ever important credit share in the U.S. And really, importantly, it gets us stickier with our merchant customers and gives us another avenue by which to sell services. Most of the co-brands that we work on have data and safety and security products and loyalty embedded in those propositions. So it's really a benefit for us on both sides of the house.

JOSEPH DEAN FORESI: Got it. And then, I mean, that leads right into the next question about services. Maybe you could talk about some services that some of your clients value outside of sort of your standard service offerings and how that's helping you kind of continue to build brand within the market. Maybe some examples would be great.

LINDA KIRKPATRICK: Happy to. So as you know, Joe, we've got 2.4 billion cards globally. We process 65 billion transactions a year. And as a result of the role that we play, we've spent decades anonymizing, cleansing our data, turning it into insights for our customers. So first and foremost, data and analytics, consulting capabilities, test and learn capabilities is paramount for merchants, in particular. Merchants are experts at the customers that come into their shop, what they do when they're there within their 4 walls. They know it better than anybody else. What they don't know is what they're doing when they're not shopping with them. And that's where Mastercard comes into play. We have visibility into the transactions outside of their stores, what other merchants they are overindexing in, what their average tickets are. And we understand how to segment those customers in a way that is very actionable for our merchant customers. We also give them the capability to test and learn new concept. So if you're an airline and you're thinking about route optimization or introducing a new route, knowing the impact and the efficacy of that change in advance of rolling it out more broadly is something that is invaluable, so that you're not a making expensive mistake. And so our proprietary Applied Predictive Technology capabilities and algorithms help them achieve that. If you're a retailer, similarly, you're looking to make a change within your store. You're looking to change the price of a product. You're looking to renovate certain properties. Knowing how to make your best in the wisest way possible without making expensive mistakes. These are things that we can help them with. So the co-brand examples that I cited earlier, all of them are leveraging our data and analytics in a way that makes sense for their businesses. I'd say, similarly, from a safety and security perspective, merchants love to work with us on our digital capabilities as well. So as you know, Joe, we've got a lab organization that has really helped our customers, including our merchant partners, innovate on pain points, section points at the point of sale. And so what we can do is we can take a problem statement from a merchant customer and say, "Okay. If you've got a queue problem at the point of sale and you want to make sure that your digital and your physical points of sales are connected in a way that allows you to not lose customers or make sure you can connect the dots between their shopping patterns in-store and digitally, we can help them achieve that." And we've done that in many instances, again, with co-brand partners, but we extend well beyond co-brand partners in the innovation space as well.

JOSEPH DEAN FORESI: Are the -- are these partners surprised at the information that's being retrieved and given to them in the friction points within the organization? And is -- have you ever released any steps on how much you're helping your merchant base through those services?

LINDA KIRKPATRICK: I think our merchants are incredibly surprised when they see the value that we bring to the table. They may have never worked with us before. They worked with our competitors for decades. And so they haven't had someone present the Mastercard story to them. So when they initially hear our pitch, they're surprised at the depth and breadth of our ability to certainly help them with their co-brand and their acquisitions and marketing efforts, but go well beyond the co-brand in all areas of support, whether that be AI, whether that be tokenization. The multiple areas that we've invested in, we're turning that into tools and services and products that the acceptance side of the house can leverage.

JOSEPH DEAN FORESI: Yes. I assume it strengthens the relationship kind of from beginning to end, right, once you start to provide them with that level of opportunity?

LINDA KIRKPATRICK: It does.

JOSEPH DEAN FORESI: The button Masterpass, can you talk about how adoption has gone with that and why networks are accepting it and continuing to adopt it?

LINDA KIRKPATRICK: Yes. So Masterpass, for those that don't know, is our digital checkout option in a digital point-of-sale environment. It is being migrated over to something called SRC, or secure remote commerce. And SRC, very simply, is an EMVCo set of standards for digital checkout. And what it's going to do is it's going to drive benefits to merchants, consumers and issuers across a variety of continuum. As it's no surprise to anyone today, the digital checkout environment can be a bit confusing and cluttered. And from our perspective, our ability to make that frictionless is going to be beneficial for commerce as a whole. Last quarter, e-commerce within our ecosystem grew 24%. And so we know that we have to follow the customer and their preferences in the way they want to check out. And so SRC is going to be a way to, really, first and foremost, be directed by merchant and consumer choice. And it's going to be a way for consumers to leverage one checkout option for multiple brands. So the best way to describe it is when you go into a store today, Joe, and you go to pay with your Mastercard, they don't tell you to use a specific terminal. They have one terminal that can accept all payment brands. We want to create that very ubiquitous experience in the digital form as well. And SRC is the way to do that. So when you think about it from the constituents' perspective, you have the consumer that has one place to go for checkout. You have the merchant who can benefit from one implementation and so it will just cause no operational issues for them. And then you have the issuer who's issued the card who can benefit from having their brand at the fore and reduce fraud at checkout. So it's really a win-win-win for all parties involved and, again, all with the premise of creating merchant choice and consumer choice at that checkout.

JOSEPH DEAN FORESI: And over to tokenization, how important is tokenization for the digital payment world? And how does Mastercard do tokenization?

LINDA KIRKPATRICK: Well, tokenization, I would say, is the foundation for the future of commerce. So you've probably seen lots of announcements on connected devices and Internet of Things. And from a Mastercard perspective, we've had no shortage of announcements. Connected fridge, connected washing machine, interactive shopping mirror at the retailer. And all of these devices are made possible -- the connectivity is made possible through tokenization. So if it's the payment app on your connected watch or another piece of jewelry, that is effectuated through tokenization. And all tokenization really is, is a fancy word for taking a 16-digit number and converting it from a static number to a dynamic crypto. And that number changes each and every time a consumer is leveraging that product. So it really renders the card useless to a fraudster who scrapes it from one place and tries to use it in another location. And it's just an incredibly important means of transacting for the future. So we've placed a lot of investment in it on our end. We're working with our partners, both on the issuing side and on the acceptance side to roll it out. On the issuing side, globally, we have over 75% of our cards are capable of tokenization in some form. On the merchant side, we also have large recurring bill pay merchants where they've -- we've got some good momentum with them rolling out tokenization efforts as well. So really critically important to the future of commerce.

JOSEPH DEAN FORESI: Let's talk about contactless payments. I think when Apple Pay first came out, everyone assumed that people would automatically default to it. And if you look globally, the adoption rates of contactless payments are much higher in different regions. Maybe you can talk about what's different globally versus here in the U.S. and maybe provide your views on sort of how you see the contactless environment evolving here.

LINDA KIRKPATRICK: Sure. So in the U.S., I'd say, we've been a little bit of a victim of our maturity as a payments ecosystem. So when we started within the U.S., we've had over 10 million merchants who accept payments, had terminals up until 3 years ago that really weren't -- most of which weren't capable of contactless payments. And so we had a little bit of an inflection point 2.5 years ago with the implementation of EMV at the point of sale where most merchants brought in new terminals that have contactless capability. And so today, in the U.S., you've got, from a Mastercard perspective, about 40% of our transactions happen at merchants who already have this capability embedded. And think about the Walgreens, the Starbucks, McDonald's of the world. But again, here, you have a chicken and egg game. You need not only the merchant to accept the contactless capability, but you need a form factor, whether it's a physical card or a phone or some other device that has that capability. And you then -- at the same time, you need consumer awareness and you need merchant awareness at the point of sale. And so to get all these things to happen at the same time is no small feat. But here in the U.S., I do believe we are at another inflection point, which is the reissuance cycle for those EMV cards that were issued almost 3 years ago is happening right now as we speak. And more and more, issuers are seeing the benefit of contactless capabilities in the markets that are outside the U.S., which have much more mature contactless capabilities. U.K., Australia, Canada, Poland, they adopted payments in a different way that the U.S. did. And they had issuers in their markets issue those cards. And consumers very directly saw the benefit of using them at the point of sale, 3 times the usage and the stickiness with the contactless card as well as the same level of safety and security that an EMV card brings with it. So really just the most enhanced friction-free experience at the point of sale you can possibly imagine. I think the other inflection point that we have right now, in addition to a lot of great issuer interest in contactless, is transit. So right here where we're sitting in New York, we have the MTA, which is undergoing a -- an overhaul of their payment system. And we're actually working with their integrator right now to implement contactless capability into the new way to pay with the MTA. And when you think about the millions of commuters that will be leveraging that system starting next year, that brings about the everyday use case that you really need to drive contactless into the ecosystem. So very similar to what happened in London with their transit system. That has the potential to happen right here in the U.S. And by the way, not just in New York, but in Boston, in Chicago and lots of other cities who are doing the exact same thing. So while it's taken some time for all the parties to come to the table, I believe we are at an inflection point in our marketplace right now where contactless is at the cusp of really taking off. And I think it will benefit anyone who participates in payment. Again, reducing that pain point, reducing that friction, making the card top of wallet and adding the highest level of safety and security on the product is a win for everybody.

JOSEPH DEAN FORESI: So with contactless sort of right there ready to go, that would increase the cash to card conversion and, perhaps, by reducing the friction, increase the amount of payments. I mean...

LINDA KIRKPATRICK: No doubt. And again, the easiest way to convert cash and check is in everyday use cases. So it's your coffee, it's your transit payments, it's your fast food purchase. And again, once a consumer is hooked with those items, it's not long before they start making that card top of wallet and really converting every form of payment into an electronic one.

JOSEPH DEAN FORESI: Right. I wonder if you could talk about competition for a minute. It's -- there's different areas of competition in different realms, right? I mean, the amount of people at the point of sale never seems to be bigger than it is right now, including some of the big tech players. You got PayPal within e-commerce. So how do you see the competition shaking out? And how does Mastercard stay ahead of the others that could be there for potential disintermediation?

LINDA KIRKPATRICK: Well, so from a PayPal perspective, since you brought them up, they are a very close partner of Mastercard. So we've struck up an agreement with them a few years ago where they agreed to not steer payments to ACH. And we've worked with them on other capabilities that we're enhancing their product flip. So we work with them in many different capacities. In some instances, a merchant. In some instances, stage digital wallets, which we have rules around in our ecosystem. And in other instances, they may compete with us from a Masterpass or SRC perspective. So we're very familiar with working with partners like PayPal in multiple capacities. And from our perspective, we need to obviously keep an eye out for the competitive threats. But we also need to partner with them in order for -- we have a collective interest. And that interest is to convert as much cash and check to electronic forms of payment. We can only really do that when we come together and align and partner.

JOSEPH DEAN FORESI: Got it. And what about the big tech side of the house from a competitive standpoint? How do you think about the Apples and the Amazons? We had an Amazon person here for lunch. How do they -- is it a partnership and hopefully we continue to stay partnerships over a long period of time? How do you think about their influence on the system?

LINDA KIRKPATRICK: Yes. And similarly, with Amazon, we have a great partnership with them. We have co-brand programs with them outside the United States. We work with them on our products and solutions that we're embedding within their ecosystem. So there might be some areas like Amazon Payments, for example, where we do compete. But again, for the whole -- for the good of the ecosystem, a partnership perspective is the approach that we take.

JOSEPH DEAN FORESI: Got it. Two last ones. We covered a lot of different topics. Which one is really exciting for you and you're spending a lot of your time on these days on the merchant side of things? Which one stands out above all the other ones if you had to choose one?

LINDA KIRKPATRICK: Yes. So I think the co-brand conversation that we had earlier is something that we've been focused on for quite a while. Again, we've had some great success. We're very proud of the position that we're in today. And we're going to keep focusing on that, for obvious reasons. And then the other is services. Being able to approach the payments ecosystem on the acceptance side with our services is something that we've been ramping up. We've been investing in. We've been making acquisitions in to make sure that we're embedding the needs of those ecosystem players into our strategy and into our go-to-market. And so very excited about the opportunity to extend our services in all different types of verticals. We recently signed a partnership with a large health care organization called Orlando Health, and they're going to be leveraging our APT capabilities in their ecosystem. And a couple of years ago, that's not something we would have ever dreamed of, a partnership with a healthcare system on data. So it's absolutely exciting to see the different opportunities ahead of us with respect to services and the acceptance side of the house.

JOSEPH DEAN FORESI: Yes. The last one, one of the kind of crossover themes between all the panels that we've had today is that it seems like from a technology perspective, the 2 are sort of intersecting. In other words, we made our way through automation and it now becomes a question of the data, rather than data being able to run machine learning in different optics around the data. Are we just scratching the surface there? Because it seems like it could be a massive runway that's just beginning to be tapped. Can you just provide us a little bit of color around that thought?

LINDA KIRKPATRICK: Yes. So we acquired a company called Brighterion, which is a company that brings AI into the fold. And so what we've been doing for a while is integrating AI capabilities into our data, especially into our fraud data to help make it smarter and more dynamic. And I do think there's multiple applications of both AI and blockchain that we've only just started to really fully understand and test and work with our FIs as well as our merchant partners to roll out. So I do think there's lots of opportunity in the future on the data front to just make everything that we do better, smarter and faster.

JOSEPH DEAN FORESI: Great. I'll leave it there, Linda. Thank you very much. Appreciate it.

LINDA KIRKPATRICK: My pleasure. Thank you.

Corporate Participants

* Craig Vosburg

Mastercard Incorporated - President of North America

Conference Call Participants

* Lisa Ann Dejong Ellis

MoffettNathanson LLC - Partner

Presentation

LISA ANN DEJONG ELLIS, PARTNER, MOFFETTNATHANSON LLC: All right. We're on? Can you hear me? All right. Welcome. I think we're going to get started. Thanks to everyone for joining us for our very first Payments, Processors and IT Services Conference here at MoffettNathanson. I'm very excited about the next 2 days. And thanks to all of you for being MoffettNathanson subscribers, being early subscribers and early supporters of our franchise here at MoffettNathanson.

And we are ready to kick it off. We have -- very delighted to be kicking off this morning with Craig Vosburg, the President of North America from Mastercard. Craig is our leadoff batter for today. So Craig, welcome. Thanks for joining us.

CRAIG VOSBURG, PRESIDENT OF NORTH AMERICA, MASTERCARD INCORPORATED: Yes. Thank you. It's a nice lineup, I have to say, with me the leadoff.

Questions and Answers

LISA ANN DEJONG ELLIS: Exactly. I know. Lead us off with a home run, I guess. All right. Let's start off with Mastercard. Craig, you are President of North America for Mastercard. The U.S. is Mastercard's largest market. I think card penetration in the U.S., last we looked at it, is running somewhere in the mid-60s. So with that in mind, can you just give us an update on your regional strategy for North America in these regions where card penetration is relatively high already?

CRAIG VOSBURG: Sure. Yes, I'll be happy to. Well, as you mentioned, North America is obviously an important region for us. And the U.S. in particular represents about 1/3 of our revenue globally. It is, however, despite the penetration rates that you referenced, one -- a market that we continue to look at as one that represents a great opportunity for growth for us. And so our strategy in North America is very consistent with our strategy around the rest of the world. And it's focused really on doing the things that we can do to continue to grow our core business, to diversify our revenue streams by broadening the customers that we serve, the range of services that we provide and looking to build new businesses that will add new streams of revenue going into the future.

So specifically, what that means for us in North America is focusing on activities to grow the core by increasing the distribution of our products in the marketplace and driving market share gains in our core products of debit, credit, commercial and prepaid products. There's opportunity to continue to grow that not just through increasing market share, which I'm happy to say we've been successful in doing across each of those products over the last number of years, but by continuing to increase the usage of those products. And despite a penetration rate in the mid-60s, as it relates to payments consumers make to merchants for the purchase of goods or services, that still leaves a nice runway for additional growth. Mid-60s in a $12 trillion or $13 trillion flow of payments in the U.S. leaves a lot of dollars yet to go after.

So getting more products in the market to be able to put us in a position to capture those flows, continuing to focus on expanding acceptance. Acceptance is such an important part of the network value proposition and an important driver of growth for us, by getting acceptance into new areas for consumers to be able to use our products: Whether that's verticals that typically haven't been used for carded payments like rent and education; whether that's new areas like small-ticket transactions, which have been sort of a bastion for cash and represent an opportunity for us to go after; whether that's making sure our acceptance capabilities are enabled on any device that's connected and capable of communicating as the Internet of Things expands the framework of how we think about acceptance opportunities.

And in doing that we're not only expanding the reach, we're working to upgrade the quality of acceptance with EMV rollout in the U.S. and now contactless. So that's an important piece of it, focusing on digital, working really closely with a wide variety of partners across the digital ecosystem and making sure that we're doing everything possible to provide account-to-account connectivity across any account to any account to be able to move money, and do it with a great user experience in a safe and secure way that's leveraging the newest innovations in technology available.

We're continuing to build out our services capabilities, value-added services, which for us has been a really important revenue driver not just globally but true in North America and the U.S. as well. The things we're doing around consulting and data analytics and information services and fraud and safety solutions and loyalty. And then finally, looking to some businesses that we think will be a big part of our future in building new businesses to capture B2B flows in a more meaningful way, B2C flows, P2P flows and building out the infrastructure and the products and the services that we need to be able to really penetrate that opportunity.

So those are the things that we're focusing on in North America and in the U.S. market, consistent to a large degree with what we're doing globally with some different weightings and different emphasis just based on the level of maturity and the stage of development of our markets here.

LISA ANN DEJONG ELLIS: All right. So Mastercard has made a handful of acquisitions recently, 4 at least since the beginning of the year, in areas like fraud, cross-border, installment payments and bill payments. How do these types of acquisitions impact your business in North America?

CRAIG VOSBURG: Well, we have been busy the last few months in adding some great new capabilities and some great new talent to the organization. Each of which -- each of the areas that mentioned where we've announced acquisitions over the last 4 or 5 months are very consistent with the pillars of the strategy that I've just described.

So Transfast as an example is -- we see as an integral part of accelerating our ability to participate in account-to-account transfers anywhere in the world. Transfast gives us reach to more than 100 markets globally in order to transfer and settle funds. There is great FX capabilities and compliance capability, licenses, a great technology platform. We've been working with them in the past already as part of our Mastercard Send program. So it just -- we think will help us accelerate that objective of not just moving money on debit or credit rails, but having a variety of ways to move money from one account to another account anywhere in the world.

Ethoca is a nice addition to our fraud capabilities and in our objective of being able to reduce and hopefully eliminate the cost of fraud in the payment system. So there's a lot of things that we've done to be able to identify fraudulent activity before and during a transaction by leveraging artificial intelligence and biometrics in different ways to authenticate a user's identity. Ethoca helps us mitigate the cost of fraud after a transaction by identifying potentially fraudulent transactions, and through communications between the merchant and the issuer, prevent the shipment of goods before they go, so that lowers the cost. And to help reduce the cost of managing the chargeback process, which can be a costly endeavor as well.

Vyze gives us a nice way to extend the value of what we're doing to both -- for both merchants and banks by creating a platform to facilitate consumer lending, the origination of consumer loans at the point of sale that aren't necessarily card-based loans, they might be an installment loan, in real time at the point of sale to enable a merchant to make a sale they might not otherwise make and enable a bank to participate in originating a consumer loan that they might not otherwise get to participate in.

And who am I forgetting?

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: Transactis.

CRAIG VOSBURG: Transactis. Thank you. A prompt from the crowd. Transactis was the most recent one that we've announced, which is aligned with our bill pay strategy. That gives us, again, a great technology platform, great talent, great connectivity into a variety of banks that they've been working with to serve the bill pay market with a platform that enables the electronic presentment of bills to consumers to facilitate a more streamlined payments process.

So all of these things and other things that you'll see us do, they line up with the pillars of that strategy and they're all intended to help us execute more quickly, more effectively to take advantage of the opportunities we see in the market.

LISA ANN DEJONG ELLIS: Continuing on the bill payment theme, because back at the beginning of the discussion, you were talking about one of the big areas of untapped spend still in North America are verticals, many of which are in areas like bill payments, like rent payment, utility payment. What's the value proposition for Mastercard to that type of recurring biller, versus for example, just doing an ACH transfer?

CRAIG VOSBURG: Yes. So that's a great question. The bill payment space is one where we see an opportunity to just -- to bring a different kind of value proposition into the marketplace that can provide value for everyone, for -- most importantly for consumers. Because as consumers, we had a somewhat dysfunctional experience in paying bills in this market. Most of us get the majority of our bills in the mail, with then we either have to write a check or go into a biller's website to initiate electronic payment. In some cases, you might get the presentment of the bill through your e-mail account that links you back to a biller's website. There's a lot of passwords you have to remember. Just a complicated experience.

So this -- there -- the idea is to streamline that for the consumer to make it easier for the consumer to manage and pay their monthly bills by aggregating them and consolidating presentment of them digitally, electronically, ideally through the bank's site, so through the bank's mobile app. So as a banking consumer, you go in once a month or every week, whatever it is, and you see what bills have arrived in your inbox and you just click, click, click, and you pay them and you're done. That's good for the consumer.

That's good for the biller because the more electronic presentment they have, the less mail they're generating. And it's costly for billers to send paper-based bills through the mail to each of us. It's costly for billers to have to then receive a check or an ACH payment and figure out how to reconcile that against the outstanding balance in the account.

So there is economic benefits to the biller. There is experiential benefits to the consumer. Banks certainly have an interest in having consumers look to them as the hub for their monthly payments. And to the extent we can drive the aggregation of bills and the presentment of bills through your online or mobile banking app, that's something the banks would view as a positive thing to reinforce the value that they're providing to the consumer.

So with the advent of real-time payments, that gives a new avenue for making the bill payment. That won't be the only way, but it's certainly something we'll incorporate into that capability. We've got a substantial biller directory within Mastercard already that we've operated for many years. That will serve as part of the nucleus of this capability with the digital presentment and delivery to a variety of options that a consumer can then choose to make the payment, one -- some of which will still be ACH, some will be real-time payments. We'll incorporate cards as a payment option. We just think that gives consumers a much more seamless experience with greater options in terms of how they pay. That's the plan.

LISA ANN DEJONG ELLIS: All right. That's the plan.

CRAIG VOSBURG: Yes.

LISA ANN DEJONG ELLIS: Other end of the spectrum. Low -- small-dollar transactions like coffee or a pack of gum has been one of the other remaining large pools of cash in the United States. So we've been thinking about the dream of contactless payments in the United States for many, many years.

CRAIG VOSBURG: We have.

LISA ANN DEJONG ELLIS: I know. So where are we? And how quickly will we all be able to finally get rid of that last big piece of cash?

CRAIG VOSBURG: I'm here to tell you the dream is here. The dream has arrived. So we have been talking about contactless for probably more than a decade in this market. And we've had some false starts in this market where one side or the other has started to make some steps in that direction and it just hasn't gotten lift off. But the time is now and it really is going to happen this time, and I can tell you that for a couple of reasons.

Most importantly is that the acceptance side of the ecosystem is pretty well wired for contactless today. And that happened as a result of the EMV migration that took place in the U.S. a few years ago where merchants went through a mass reterminalization effort. Virtually all of the new terminals that went into the market had contactless hardware embedded in them. And it became then -- the decision around contactless for the merchant is one of do I activate the software on the terminal that I already have? And the vast majority of merchants are doing that.

So we see today, as a point of reference, 60% of our transaction volume in the U.S. originates from merchants who are contactless-enabled. So at 60%, that's effective ubiquity. And we see that growing. Large merchants like Target and 7-Eleven and CVS have all either added or have communicated their plans to enable contactless. So we think that's going to continue to grow. And at 60% of the volume that a consumer would originate, that's enough of a ubiquitous opportunity that it will begin to register with consumers that I can actually use this contactless device to make payments.

The other side of the equation obviously is the card side. There are devices, mobile devices in the market already that are contactless-enabled. Those will be complemented by a significant reissuance of plastics in the coming 18, 24 months, some of which is already underway. We've got a number of our issuers who have already put contactless programs into the marketplace. We have others that represent in total about 2/3 of our cards in the market who will be issuing contactless cards over the course of the next 18 months or so. We're coming up on the beginning of the reissuance cycle from the original chip cards that will help facilitate this.

Other issuers are undertaking a forced reissuance, particularly in areas where there are real catalysts for usage like transit systems. And we were joking this morning, the MTA is finally here. We've been talking about the MTA going contactless for a long time. Their pilot to introduce contactless payments at the turnstile is now underway. On the 4, 5, 6 line, it's live. And the MTA will introduce contactless capabilities up at all subway stations, on all bus lines, over the course of the next 18 months or so. They're not alone. There's another 15 or 18 transit systems across the country that are doing the same thing or are already live.

And we see market-after-market, when transit goes live, it's an incredible catalyst for changing consumer behavior and creating a daily use case for tapping a card, which is such a better experience than going and purchasing a closed loop stored value card. And once consumers start using it in a place like a transit turnstile, they start to look for terminals where they can use it everywhere.

And it's a great business case. There's a great business case behind it for us and for the banks. We see consumers who are engaged in contactless increase their level of usage anywhere from 30% to 80% is what we've seen in markets around the world. So we're excited about it. We're working really hard with our banking partners and with our merchant partners to expedite the rollout of contactless. And we see it as a really important development for us in the market here.

LISA ANN DEJONG ELLIS: All right. Speaking of important developments. Apple launched the Apple Card with a lot of...

CRAIG VOSBURG: Yes. It did. Communicated it.

LISA ANN DEJONG ELLIS: Communicated. That's true. Communicated about the Apple Card with a fair bit of fanfare. The Apple Card is riding on Mastercard's rails. CRAIG VOSBURG: I think the -- to me, the importance of this from an investor point of view is that it represents a really important sort of proof point of the benefit of investments we've been making in a couple of areas: In our technology most notably and in our partnerships. And by -- what I mean by that is with our technology, the Apple Card, the Apple Pay, there are a number of other examples of this, it rides on the back of Mastercard technology, most specifically our tokenization capabilities, fraud solutions and other things that are incorporated as well. But the investment in that technology as the basis, the foundation for them being able to work with partners like Apple and Goldman Sachs to think about how to deploy that in new and creative ways to meet the needs of consumers in the way they want to meet them. And Apple and Goldman are the creators of the experience ultimately then that their consumers will enjoy in conjunction with that card.

The investment in technology and the investment in those partners and partnerships and relationships have enabled us to then work creatively to develop this program that we think is going to be pretty exciting and it's going to be unique. And it's going to enable consumers to effectively apply, be approved and have a payment credential provisioned to their device and effectively in real time, which is a pretty unique experience, again, riding on the back of our tokenization capabilities and obviously other things that both Apple and Goldman bring to the equation.

And it is one of what I hope will be many proof points in how we can utilize the technology that we're investing in, the capabilities we're building, the things we're acquiring to then work with partners in creative ways to meet the needs of consumers and businesses in ways that are consistent with the way they want to serve them, their strategy for deepening engagement with their customer base. LISA ANN DEJONG ELLIS: All right. Well, speaking of big tech. Talk a little bit about that relationship and how that relationship has evolved over time.

CRAIG VOSBURG: Yes. That's a great question. Our relationship with PayPal has evolved, I would say, dramatically over the last, I don't know, 5, 7 years, where we've always -- there's always been an important business connection with PayPal because obviously they -- there's a lot of payments volume that is initiated through PayPal's platform that has always incorporated the use of a lot of Mastercard products, and therefore, it's an important source of originated payments volume for us.

But the partnership has evolved in ways that has become much deeper and more strategic over the last handful of years. And I would credit that in large part really, I know Dan's on the agenda later today, to a shift in thinking that was very important I think under Dan's leadership in centering the strategy around enabling consumer choice. And with that, we were able to have a very different dialogue around how do we ensure that consumers are able to make the choices that are of most importance to them around how they pay and their knowledge of the products that they're using, et cetera.

So most fundamental to that shift for us was aligning around the strategic intent of enabling choice, which includes enabling consumers to choose a Mastercard product as their default payment product. They have other choices as well, other card products, and they still can choose ACH if that's what they want. But ensuring that there was clarity of choice and the ability to set Mastercard product as their preferred product, to know that it was a Mastercard product, see the branding and to ensure that we were working together to make sure we had the right kind of data flows coming back and forth as part of the transaction. So we knew we had the right transaction data that was clean, the issuer had the data they needed to manage things like fraud and rewards and that sort of thing and the consumer can see clearly what it was they were spending on. That was a really important foundation to build upon.

And while on the back of that, we ventured into -- we were the first network to enter into a global strategic partnership with them to leverage things like our tokenization capabilities to expand the applicability and use of the PayPal wallet. We've worked with them very closely to embed Mastercard Send as a means of moving money in and out of the PayPal and Venmo ecosystems. So that consumers can choose, if they want to, to move money easily into a bank account or to cash out value that they might have in either of those stored accounts.

And of course with that, we've built really important commercial partnerships with card programs and not just in the U.S. but around the world. PayPal and Venmo have debit and credit programs that are branded Mastercard. I think all of their programs are Mastercard-branded around the world. And they each had a great platform that, indeed, the consumers care about. And we see that in the engagement with those products and we're really happy to be their partner. That's all on the issuing side.

Of course, there is also a really important role that PayPal plays with respect to Braintree and the work that they do on the merchant side of the ecosystem. And they're great partners there, too, in terms of working with us to think about how to extend the reach of electronic payments and do it in the ways that provide the right kind of consumer experience, the right kind of security and fraud management.

So you may have the same question for Dan later today and I'll be interested to see what his answer is. But from our perspective, it's a really strong partnership and we're excited about where that can go.

LISA ANN DEJONG ELLIS: And maybe just a follow-on on that. A unique component of, say, the Venmo card is that it's one of these prepaid debit cards essentially, right, issued against the stored balance in the Venmo account. We sort of see a little bit of proliferation of that type of model. Where do you think that's headed? Is that, in your view, a niche product relative to, say, the debit cards that are being issued against an actual checking account, where you've got these prepaid cards like the Apple Pay cash card or like this one? Those are -- now we see them in a handful of places in the U.S. Where do you see that going?

CRAIG VOSBURG: I think there is the potential for these things that started in sort of a -- in very distinct use cases. Obviously, a checking account that a bank might offer, a credit union has a range of functionality associated with it. A platform like Venmo as an example or some of the other P2P platforms had very distinct use cases around transferring money between individuals. But to the extent you have money at rest, in either case, it just adds utility to the consumer to increase the ways in which they can use those funds rather than just leave them in account -- in an account.

And then naturally it leads to a little bit of a narrowing of the gap, I think. I don't think they ultimately completely overlap unless some of those other organizations choose to become banks, which I'd be surprised if they did because there's a lot of other inconvenient things that come along with being a bank.

But certainly, from the consumer point of view, enhancing the utility of how they can actually access and utilize funds that are -- it's their money, as well as enable the easier management of funds. Some of these are evolving in ways that just help consumers with budgeting and cash flow management and parking money in a place that effectively gives them an allowance for a certain portion of their expenditures in a given month. We're seeing some models evolve in that way, and I think that's a useful development for consumers. But I don't think that, that ultimately completely replaces what we see in a full service DDA relationship.

LISA ANN DEJONG ELLIS: And from Mastercard's perspective, do you care? I mean, are you pretty agnostic?

CRAIG VOSBURG: We're agnostic. Our objective is to -- we want to serve the needs of our business partners in meeting the needs of consumers in ways that consumers care about. So we want to do that in the ways that are consistent with our brand in terms of providing a great consumer experience, widespread utility riding on the back of our acceptance infrastructure, global interoperability, safety and security, convenience, et cetera. And we work with a variety of partners, as you know, in order to deliver that. Some of them are commercial banks, some are community banks and credit unions, some are digital challengers in the space. They all have different ways in which they add value to consumers and businesses, and we want to serve the needs of that -- of those end users.

And by the way, not just through debit or credit cards, but through, as I said, being able to move money from any account to any account anywhere in the world and putting as much choice out there in the market to enable our partners to craft the value propositions that are most relevant for them in executing a strategy is -- that's what we're up to.

And there's lots of ways to get money from one account to another account and we want to have as many of those available to us and our partners as possible so that they can craft the right things for them to meet the needs of their customers.

LISA ANN DEJONG ELLIS: And just a follow-on question on that. In your discussion, your partnership discussions with these players, where do you draw the line or where do they draw the line? CRAIG VOSBURG: That's a good question. I felt we -- I guess I'd say we -- there's -- we're managing the payments ecosystem, the payments infrastructure and the Mastercard network with a view towards all of our various constituents who are a part of that, right? So there are areas where the role of the network is to look out for all of the parties in the ecosystem who are connected to the network and as well as the consumers and the businesses who are using our products and services.

So there are things where we see -- there are things that are particularly important with us that are things to tie back to what our brand stands for and what our various partners that we work with expect from us. And they expect us to make sure that things are going to be safe and secure. They expect us to make sure that we're working in ways that are compliant with the various regulations that our partners need to adhere to. They're expecting that the things that have our brand on it are continuing to deliver the right kind of consumer experience. LISA ANN DEJONG ELLIS: All right. So speaking of these platforms, many of which are facilitating e-commerce of various forms. E-commerce growth has been and continues to be a material tailwind to your business for the simple reason that virtually all e-commerce is made with card. But at the same time, it has a dynamic where very large volumes of spending aggregate through fewer large platforms. So how do you think about e-commerce, the trends there? And what do you see as the opportunities versus, say, the risks?

CRAIG VOSBURG: So you're right that we see this as a real -- a very important driver of growth for the business. Just to put it in context, e-commerce is still a distinct minority of our overall volume. It's 12%, 13%, something like that of the total, but it's growing at 3 to 4x the rate of physical commerce. So that percentage is steadily increasing. And as you suggested, it is an important driver of the secular shift because there are fewer alternatives to electronic payments when it comes to e-commerce.

So our play there is all about ensuring that we're doing everything we can to make Mastercard, our products and our capabilities not just relevant but really compelling in a digital world. And that starts with, again, thinking it more broadly than debit and credit and thinking about how to connect any account to any account, doing it in a way that provides and ensures a really great consumer experience. And this is an area where, frankly, with the advent of a lot of these digital players who are the "digital natives" who have grown their businesses on the back of providing really compelling consumer experience, this is an area for us that's an important one to make sure we keep pace. And we're providing through our partners, whether that partner is a bank or a merchant, an equally compelling user experience and doing it in a way that ensures the safety and integrity of the payments.

So a lot of our focus and investment there is around, when we think about the payments occasions in digital commerce, there are ways in which you pay, you might pay through a digital wallet, you might pay through a guest checkout experience, you might have credentials on file that you have the card on file with the merchant that you shop with regularly.

The work we've done with wallets has been well discussed and we'll continue to do that. And wallets provide their own sort of unique consumer experience. Our work is now focusing very heavily on improving the guest checkout experience, which is not a good consumer experience today. That's the impetus behind the Secure Remote Commerce standard that we're rolling out in the U.S. later this year, along with the other EMVCo members, to create a much more consistent and user-friendly experience in the guest checkout use case to prevent people from having to type in all this information, their card credentials, their address, all that stuff, to make it a very seamless and intuitive and convenient process to check out while also being secure. So that, that particular set of payments occasions is improved and consistent, we hope, with what consumers are seeing elsewhere.

The card on file use case, which is a very significant amount of transaction activity, is a pretty good user experience but it's not as secure as it needs to be. And therefore a lot of our focus there is working with partners to tokenize those credentials and swap out the 16-digit card number with a token to ensure the security of those credentials while they're at rest in the card on file environment and when they are being used. And with both of those transaction types to enhance the security of the transaction with greater authentication capabilities by increasing the flow of information between the merchant and the bank so that they can make a better decision in approving transactions that are legitimate and declining transactions that aren't.

So that's our focus in ensuring that as the digital and e-commerce environment continues to grow, we're making that a great consumer experience in any -- regardless of the kind of use case in terms of how the consumer's paying and that we're ensuring that there's the right level of security that underpins the transaction.

LISA ANN DEJONG ELLIS: And the big commerce sites, do those pose, like, a pricing pressure? Do those end up putting some pricing pressure back on Mastercard?
